Nonsinusoidal periodic functions

The following are examples of non-sinusoidal periodic functions (they are often called "waves").

Square wave


Analytically we can describe this function as follows:

  \[ \begin{align} f(t) = \begin{cases} -1 &-\pi < t < 0 \\ +1 &0 < t < \pi \end{cases} \end{align} \text{(which gives the definition over one period)} \]

\[ f(t + 2\pi) = f(t) \hspace{1cm} \text{(which tells us that the function has period } 2\pi ) \]

Saw-tooth waves


In this case we can describe the function as follows: \[ f(t) = 2t \hspace{1cm} 0 < t < 2 \hspace{1cm} f(t+2) = f(t) \] Here the period is \(2\), the frequency is \( \dfrac{1}{2}\) and the angular frequency is \(\dfrac{2\pi}{2} = \pi\).

Triangular waves


Here we can conveniently define the function using \( -\pi < t < \pi\) as the "basic period": \[ \begin{align} f(t) = \begin{cases} -t &-\pi < t < 0 \\ t &0 < t < \pi \end{cases} \end{align} \] or, more concisely, \[ f(t) = \lvert t \rvert \hspace{2cm} -\pi < t < \pi \] together with the usual statement on periodicity \[ f(t + 2\pi) = f(t).\]
